text.content:
Desolation of the Dead

Desolation of the Dead is a three-part adventure that takes the Acolytes into the depths of Hive Desoleum's Gallowsway district, where a Nurgle cult called the Blessed Flesh is reanimating the dead and preparing to summon a Herald of the Plague God.

Part I: A Trip to the Gallows

The Acolytes are dispatched to investigate a mass murder in the Gallowsway, a decaying section of lower Desoleum City dedicated to dealing with the dead. Among the victims they discover a xenos artefact and the body of Darnis Fayne. Investigation leads through the Carrion Guilds, the Drains, the Boneyard, and ultimately to the Fayne Mortuarius, where the Blessed Flesh cult operates in secret.

Part II: The Red Walk

Following the body trade trail downhive, the Acolytes pass through the Purity Gate into Gantry—a rogue settlement ruled by Vornas Crimson and his Red Walk gang. The Acolytes must navigate gang politics, the blood sports of the Knife Lock pit, and forge an uneasy alliance before the animated dead launch an assault on the settlement.

Part III: A Pestilent Heart

The Acolytes descend into the sump-swamp and wild Underhive ruins to reach the Blessed Flesh's lair—a massive archeotech construction platform rising from the toxic river. They must infiltrate the fortress, confront Ferrue Fayne, and stop the summoning ritual before Aynthrexes, Herald of Nurgle, is brought fully into reality.

GM Notes

Desolation of the Dead is the second act of the Desoleum trilogy, following Dark Pursuits (Core Rulebook) and preceding Forgotten Gods. It can be run as a standalone adventure with minimal adjustment.

Key Themes

  • Corruption and Decay: The physical rot of the Gallowsway mirrors the spiritual corruption of the Blessed Flesh cult. Even the dead are not allowed rest.
  • Body Trade: The Carrion Guilds process thousands of corpses daily. Ferrue has corrupted this system, stealing bodies for reanimation and selling organs to the underhive.
  • Nurgle's Embrace: The adventure builds from a mundane murder investigation into a confrontation with daemonic forces. Each act escalates the Warp taint.

Using This Adventure with Dark Pursuits

This adventure can be used as a sequel to Dark Pursuits, the scenario found in the Core Rulebook. Dark Pursuits deals with the trafficking of xenos artefacts within Hive Desoleum, and can easily be connected via the xenos artefact Ferrue has acquired. It is likely that Ferrue has had dealings with the Trade Sable, and some NPCs from Dark Pursuits might have passed his name onto the Acolytes.

Starting Characters

Recommended starting XP: 1000–2000 XP. New characters can handle the early investigation, but the final confrontation with Aynthrexes is extremely dangerous for inexperienced Acolytes.

name: Part I: A Trip to the Gallows

text.content:
The Gallowsway

The Gallowsway is a dank and forgotten place perched on the under-edges of Desoleum City. Very little in the way of wealth from the hive trickles down here, nor do power, light, or food. It is home to thousands of unclaimed corpses, sent each day from the poorer sections of the city above for disposal. They fester in monumental warehouses before being processed in the level's numerous Mortuarius Factorums. It is a foul place to live, but one that must exist lest the city become choked with its own dead.

Charnel House 17

Each of the major Carrion Guild families maintains a house to store the dead before processing. The Fayne family maintains Charnel House 17, and it is likely the Acolytes' first stop. It bears a crumbling façade of huge faces from old Desoleum, and within its dank halls lie rows upon rows of stone slabs bearing the dead. The scene of the mass murder is here—a tangle of corpses bearing strange marks, among them the body of Darnis Fayne and a fragment of the xenos artefact.

A successful Challenging (+0) Awareness test reveals that many of the corpses at the scene appear to have been dead for far longer than the murders would suggest—some are weeks old. A Difficult (−10) Medicae test confirms several bodies show signs of having been previously preserved using Carrion Guild techniques, then somehow reanimated.

The Drains

Beneath the Gallowsway, a network of ancient drainage tunnels connects the Charnel Houses to the lower reaches. Known locally as the Drains, they are used by bonepickers, scavengers, and those who wish to move unseen. The Blessed Flesh cult uses them to transport stolen corpses to the Fayne Mortuarius.

The tunnels are dark, cramped, and foul-smelling. Characters without a light source suffer −30 to Perception-based tests. The Drains are also home to various vermin and the occasional mutant creature that feeds on the detritus of the dead.

The Boneyard

The Boneyard is a vast open space where the remains of processed corpses are dumped—mountains of bones stretching into the darkness. It serves as an informal market for bone-scavengers and is one of the few open areas in the Gallowsway. The locals are suspicious of outsiders but can be persuaded to share rumours about the Fayne brothers with a successful Ordinary (+10) Charm or Challenging (+0) Intimidate test.

The Fayne Mortuarius

The Fayne family's processing facility is a massive factorum where the dead are rendered for useful materials—meat, fluids, and bones. Under Ferrue's control, it has become a front for the Blessed Flesh cult. Within its depths, the Acolytes find evidence of the body trade and Ferrue's reanimation experiments. This is the first major confrontation with the cult, as Blessed Flesh members attempt to prevent the Acolytes from uncovering their operations.

Gantry Settlement

Beyond the Purity Gate lies Gantry—a rogue settlement built on rusted gantries and catwalks above the sump-river. It is ruled by Vornas Crimson and his Red Walk gang, Fleshcutters all who live for bladed combat. The settlement exists in a lawless zone between the lower hive and the true Underhive, and serves as a waystation for the body trade between the Gallowsway and the depths below.

Vornas is ostensibly Ferrue's ally, but has little love for the cult leader. The Acolytes have a good chance to turn him to their cause—or take him out of the struggle. A successful Challenging (+0) Charm or Difficult (−10) Intimidate test can open negotiations.

The Knife Lock

The Knife Lock is the Red Walk's blood sport arena—a caged pit where challengers fight with blades for the entertainment of Gantry's inhabitants. Participating (and winning) earns the respect of the Red Walk and can open doors that diplomacy cannot. Combat in the Knife Lock follows standard melee rules, but the confined space (3m diameter) means no character may Disengage or move more than 2 metres.

The Dead Attack

While the Acolytes are in Gantry, Ferrue dispatches a wave of animated corpses to assault the settlement. This serves a dual purpose: testing the capabilities of his risen forces, and attempting to eliminate the Acolytes. The attack comes without warning as shambling corpses emerge from the sump-river and climb the gantry supports.

The assault uses 2d5+3 Animated Corpses (see NPCs Appendix). If Vornas Crimson is still alive and has been turned to the Acolytes' cause, he and his Red Walk Gangers fight alongside the Acolytes. The Dead ignore the Red Walk and focus on the Acolytes unless directly engaged.

After the attack, Vornas (or his successor, if he has been killed) can point the Acolytes toward the Blessed Flesh lair downriver—somewhere in the sump-swamp below Gantry.

The Underhive Descent

The journey from Gantry to the Blessed Flesh lair takes the Acolytes deep into the sump-swamp and the wild ruins of the Underhive. A perilous journey in its own right, the Acolytes must contend with rogue gangers, mutant families, and sightless horrors that lurk in the toxic waters. Navigation requires a Difficult (−10) Navigate (Surface) test; failure adds 1d5 hours to the journey and triggers a random encounter.

The Blessed Flesh Hideout

The Blessed Flesh lair is hidden in the remains of a massive archeotech construction platform—a veritable fortress rising from the toxic river. It is protected by cultists, animated corpses, and trapped passages. Within, Ferrue Fayne conducts his experiments surrounded by vats of preservative chemicals and the reanimated dead.

The Acolytes can approach through stealth (using the sump-river and service tunnels), force (a direct assault on the main entrance), or guile (disguising themselves as cult supplicants). Each approach has its advantages and risks.

Confronting Ferrue Fayne

Ferrue is found in the heart of the lair, preparing the summoning ritual. He is protected by his most devoted cultists and a retinue of animated corpses. If confronted, he fights with his Force Staff and psychic powers while attempting to complete the ritual. He is fanatical and will not surrender—the power of the xenos artefact has driven him beyond reason.

If the Acolytes can destroy or remove the xenos artefact, Ferrue's Psy Rating drops from 4 to 3, and the summoning ritual fails. Otherwise, the ritual completes in 2d10+5 rounds after the Acolytes enter the summoning chamber.

Aynthrexes Arrives

If the ritual succeeds, Aynthrexes, Herald of Nurgle, tears through the veil between worlds. The Herald is freshly summoned and not at full strength, but is still a terrifying opponent. The Acolytes must banish or destroy the daemon before it can fully anchor itself in reality.

The Herald's Embodiment of Decay ability degrades all equipment within 10 metres to Poor craftsmanship, and its Nauseating presence forces even those who pass their Fear test to suffer Fatigue. Combined with Nurgle's Rot affecting all characters within range, the confrontation is a race against attrition.

Aftermath

If Aynthrexes is destroyed or banished and Ferrue is dealt with, the Blessed Flesh cult collapses. The xenos artefact should be recovered and turned over to the Inquisitor. The Gallowsway returns to its grim but mundane existence. If Vornas Crimson survived, he owes the Acolytes a debt—which may prove useful in Forgotten Gods.

Sanctionary Crime Report

Oath Guard Incident Report — Gallowsway Precinct

Reporting Officer: Oath-Captain K. Nils

Date: 814.M41

Location: Charnel House 17, Gallowsway District

Summary: Multiple bodies discovered during routine inspection. Total count: seventeen. Initial assessment suggests violent confrontation, but several bodies display signs of advanced decomposition inconsistent with reported time of death. One body tentatively identified as Darnis Fayne, second son of the Fayne Carrion Guild family. An item of unknown provenance was recovered from the scene—appears to be of xenos origin. Item has been secured pending specialist examination.

Notes: Crime scene contamination is significant. Several bodies appear to have moved post-mortem based on drag marks and positioning. Recommend specialist investigation. Local witnesses claim to have heard “shuffling” and “moaning” from the charnel house the night before discovery. Possible link to recent disappearances in the lower Gallowsway.

Classification: Elevated — Possible Heretical Activity

Evidence Notes — Xenos Artefact Fragment

Recovered from Charnel House 17 crime scene. Fragment appears to have broken from a larger device.

The artefact fragment is an asymmetrical piece of dark material that seems to shift slightly when not directly observed. It is painful to look at for extended periods, and proximity causes feelings of unease and mild nausea. Characters who handle the fragment unprotected must pass a Challenging (+0) Willpower test or gain 1 Corruption point.

A successful Hard (−20) Forbidden Lore (Xenos) test identifies the material as being of non-human manufacture, potentially millions of years old. A Very Hard (−30) Psyniscience test reveals the fragment resonates with Warp energy, as though it were a conduit or amplifier for psychic power.

The fragment appears to have been deliberately broken from a larger piece—tool marks are visible at the break point. This suggests someone (Darnis) took a piece of a larger artefact.

Word has reached me of disturbing activities in Hive Desoleum's bottom reaches, where it appears the foul taint of the xenos has penetrated even to these remote levels. The Sanctioned Bondsmen enforcing hive law in this wretched area report of an unnatural item found at an unusually grisly mass killing, and I have decided to make the matter my own.

You are to descend into the darkness of the Gallowsway to investigate the situation, and take whatever steps are necessary to prevent further contamination of humanity, even in these desolate depths.

In the name of the Emperor, go forth to do my bidding and carry out His Will.

Priority communiqué from Gallowsway Precinct. Oath-Captain Nils reporting.

Situation has deteriorated beyond initial assessment. Multiple sightings of... I know how this sounds, but the dead are walking. Repeat: the dead are walking in the lower Gallowsway. Charnel Houses 9, 12, and 17 all report missing bodies. Locals are in panic. I am requesting immediate reinforcement and specialist support.

We have identified a person of interest: Ferrue Fayne, second son of the Fayne Carrion Guild. He has not been seen for three days. His elder brother Tormus claims ignorance but I don't believe him. There are rumours of a cult operating in the Mortuarius district—they call themselves the Blessed Flesh.

Whatever is happening down here, it goes beyond criminal activity. I need your people. Now.

Crafting a Nemesis

While a campaign can work very well in an episodic format, the addition of a long-term antagonist can add a unique sense of cohesiveness to adventures. These enemies, referred to as Nemeses, can drive the plot of a campaign with their machinations, while finally confronting them provides an extremely satisfying showdown.

Who is the Nemesis?

The nature and origin of the Nemesis heavily informs the details of its plans and actions. Most Nemeses can be placed into one of three broad classes:

The Enemy Within

Traitors, heretics, and other malcontents within the Imperial structure make excellent Nemeses. Power-mad conspirators among the Imperium's elite are just as viable as low-life cultists. An entire group can serve as a Nemesis, such as a Chaos cult with a particularly great unity of purpose. The epitome of this sort of Nemesis could be another Inquisitor working at odds to the Acolytes' own master.

The Enemy Without

Alien threats frequently draw Inquisitorial notice. For an alien menace to work as a Nemesis, it should ideally be capable of subtlety and indirect action. The most iconic example is the enigmatic Eldar—Farseers who act ruthlessly upon any perceived threat, laying schemes over multiple human generations. Dark Eldar Archons, Tau Water Caste diplomats, and even Ork Warlords of unusual cunning can serve as Nemeses with the right approach.

The Enemy Beyond

Daemons and the servants of the Ruinous Powers represent threats of a fundamentally different nature. A daemonic Nemesis need not take the field personally; it can act through cults, possessed individuals, and corrupted artefacts. The greatest challenge of a daemonic Nemesis is its persistence—destroying a daemon's physical form merely banishes it temporarily.

Developing the Nemesis

A Nemesis should evolve as the campaign progresses. Early encounters should establish the Nemesis as a credible threat and hint at greater plans. The GM should consider:

  • Motivation: What drives the Nemesis? Power, revenge, ideology, or alien imperatives? The motivation should be consistent and understandable, even if reprehensible.
  • Resources: What does the Nemesis command? Cults, gangs, xenos technology, daemonic pacts? Resources should grow or diminish based on the Acolytes' actions.
  • Methods: How does the Nemesis operate? Through proxies, direct confrontation, manipulation, or corruption? The methods should reflect the Nemesis's nature and resources.

Nemesis Encounters

Not every encounter with the Nemesis needs to be a direct confrontation. Consider these encounter types:

  • Signs and Portents: Evidence of the Nemesis's activities—crime scenes, corrupted areas, terrified witnesses.
  • Proxy Conflicts: The Acolytes face the Nemesis's agents, servants, or creations.
  • Near Misses: The Acolytes arrive just too late, finding the Nemesis has moved on but left clues.
  • Direct Confrontation: A face-to-face encounter, which should feel earned after building tension.
  • The Final Showdown: The climactic battle, which should carry real stakes and consequences.

Nemesis Survival

A good Nemesis should have plausible escape routes built into early encounters. Teleportation, body doubles, pre-planned bolt holes, or simply being too powerful to defeat at the Acolytes' current level are all valid approaches. However, the Nemesis should never feel truly invulnerable—the Acolytes should always feel that with enough preparation and the right circumstances, they can bring their enemy down.
